CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis package¶

Submodules¶

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis module¶

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.ButterworthFilter(WF, G0, omega0, n, sign)[source]¶

Applies a “Butterworth” filter to the waveform where omega0 denotes the blending position and n the order of blending. sign determines which of the two halfes is chosen.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.CorrelationFunction(fhSI1, fhSI2, Sn, fLow, fHi)[source]¶

Computes the correlation function over a given detector by using Fourier-modes in SI units. The definition of the correlation function is given in Phys. Rev. D 44, 3819-3834, Eq. 2.6, and especially Eq. 2.8 in terms of Fourier transforms.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.FStrainToSI(h, M)[source]¶

Converts the Fourier domain strain to SI units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.FixedFrequencyIntegration(WF1, f0, k, n=0)[source]¶

Given some function and frequency f0 (ie omega0/2pi)), we apply the integration scheme proposed by Reisswig&Pollney to get the k-th integral

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.FrequenciesToSI(f, M)[source]¶

Converts a list of frequencies to SI units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GaussFilter(WF, t0, sigma0, sign)[source]¶

Applies a (half-)Gaussian filter to the waveform where t0, denotes the blending position and sigma0 the width of blending. sign determines which of the two halfes is chosen.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GaussSmooth(WF, sigma)[source]¶

Smoothes the input by convolving with a normal distribution

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GethFD(WF, wf_type='news')[source]¶

Given psi4 or the news in Fourier domain this returns h in Fourier domain

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GethFromNews(WF1, f0, n=0)[source]¶

Given the news and frequency f0 (ie omega0/2pi)), we apply the integration scheme proposed by Reisswig&Pollney to get h

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GethFromPsi4(WF1, f0, n=0)[source]¶

Given psi4 and frequency f0 (ie omega0/2pi)), we apply the integration scheme proposed by Reisswig&Pollney to get h. n denotes the number of zeros as n times length of signal

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GethFromPsi4Filtered(WF1, frange, n=0)[source]¶

Given psi4 and frequency f0 (ie omega0/2pi)), we apply the integration scheme proposed by Reisswig&Pollney by applying a filter to get h. n denotes the number of zeros as n times length of signal

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.GethTD(WF, wf_type='news', shiftToZero=False)[source]¶

Given psi4 or the news in the time domain this returns h in the time domain

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.InitModeArray(lmax)[source]¶

Creates an array with empty modes up to lmax

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.IntCharFreq(fhSI, d, Sn, fLow, fHi)[source]¶

Given a reconstructed h in SI units in Fourier domain and distance d (in Mpc) this computes the integrated characteristic signal frequency for sensitivity curve Sn

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.LoadModeArray(basename, lmax, col_time=1, col_re=2, col_im=3, filenameformat='cce_conversion_script')[source]¶

Loads an array of modes up to lmax from disk. We assume that files begin with ‘basename’ and end with _l*m*.dat

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.LuminosityDistance(z, Omega_m=0.3175, Omega_lambda=0.6825)[source]¶

Computes the luminosity distance in Mpc for a given redshift z Code from Ed Wright http://www.astro.ucla.edu/~wright/CosmoCalc.html

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.Match(hSI1, hSI2, Sn, fLow, fHi, WFtype='h')[source]¶

Computes the best match given two waveforms hSI1 and hSI2 in SI units in the time domain. The waveforms are assumed to be in the standard from h=h_+-ih_x. If WFtype is not set to ‘h’, but ‘psi4’ or ‘news’ we will perform the integration in the Fourier domain to get h

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.MinMassFromOmega(omega, fcut)[source]¶

Given a frequency omega=2*pi*f in units 1/M and a lower detector sensitivity cut-off fcut [Hz], this computes the minimum allowable mass such that fSI>=fcut, where fSI is f in SI units.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.MisMatch(hSI1, hSI2, Sn, fLow, fHi, WFtype='h')[source]¶

Same as above but 1-Match

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.NewsToSI(h, M)[source]¶

Converts time domain news to SI units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.OrthonormalBasis(hSI_plus, hSI_cross, Sn, fLow, fHi)[source]¶

Given the two linearly independent waves h_plus and h_cross in SI units and in the Fourier domain, we find an orthonormalised basis wrt to the detector inner product

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.PhaseAlignOverRange(DF1, DF2, x0, x1, start_xoff, delta, dx, accuracy=0.01, monotonic=False)[source]¶

Phase-aligns two waveforms by minimizing their difference in the L2 norm and returns the time-shift (and phase shift) that needs to be applied. The procedure is that from Boyle et al, arxiv:0804.4184v2. DF1: phase of waveform 1 DF2: phase of waveform 2 [x0,x1]: The minimization interval. start_xoff: An initial guess to speed up computation. delta: the shift will be applied in the range [start_xoff-delta, start_xoff+delta].

The smaller delta, the faster (but keep in mind that you need to be sure that the minimum is located in that range!

dx: The delta spacing of interpolated function values on which the pointwise difference is taken. accuracy: The accuracy in finding the shift that minimizes the L2 norm of the error (‘the delta spacing of the shift’). monotonic: Set to ‘True’ if function is monotonic (this will greatly speed up computation)

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.PolynomialFilterDriver(WFfr, x0, x1, blend=False)[source]¶

Given a waveform in Fourier domain, we fit a polynomial between frequncy range frange as described in Reisswig&Pollney 2010

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.Psi4ToSI(h, M)[source]¶

Converts time domain psi4 to SI units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.ReconFromsYlm(arrayWF, theta, phi, lmax)[source]¶

Given an array of WF modes h_lm reconstruct h at angle theta, phi up to l=lmax

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.Reconstruction(WF, dx, kernel, tau)[source]¶

Resamples the input to resolution dx by convolving with a reconstruction filter kernel of width tau

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.ReisswigFilter(WF1, f0, doItInFreqDomain=False, k=1, n=0)[source]¶

This filter takes the k-th derivative (optionally in the Fourier domain) and then applies Fixed-frequency integration to hi-pass filter the signal

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.Richardson_error(order, dxLow, dxHi, errorDF)[source]¶

Richardson extrapolates the errorDF assumed as given by the difference on low dxLow and hi resolution dxHi by the order specified.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SNR(fhSI, d, Sn, fLow, fHi)[source]¶

Given a reconstructed h in SI units in Fourier domain and distance d (in Mpc) this computes the SNR for sensitivity curve Sn

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SNRavg(fhSIModes, lmax, d, Sn, fLow, fHi)[source]¶

Given a modes array in SI units in Fourier domain and distance d (in Mpc) this computes the angle averaged SNR for sensitivity curve Sn

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SelecthCross(h)[source]¶

Given a complex function h=h_+-ih_x, this returns h_x

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SelecthPlus(h)[source]¶

Given a complex function h=h_+-ih_x, this returns h_+

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SensitivityAdLIGO(f)[source]¶

This curve is using most likely data points from 25. Jan. 2010, LIGO Document T0900288-v3

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SensitivityAdLIGO_Old(f)[source]¶

This curve is an old one!

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SensitivityAdVirgo(f)[source]¶
CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SensitivityBBO(f)[source]¶

From arXiv:1110.2865 For this sensitivity curve, you don’t need to select the + or x polarization component since the detector is a triangle. The 60 degree abgle between detector arms is incoproated into the noise curve. The antenna pattern is incorporated in the noise curve. For SNRs, use an additional factor of sqrt(4) since BBO consists of 4 detectors!

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.SensitivityDECIGO(f)[source]¶

From arXiv:1110.2865 For this sensitivity curve, you don’t need to select the + or x polarization component since the detector is a triangle. The 60 degree abgle between detector arms is incoproated into the noise curve. The antenna pattern is incorporated in the noise curve. For SNRs, use an additional factor of sqrt(4) since BBO consists of 4 detectors!

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.ShiftToZero(DF, trange)[source]¶

Given a range [.,.] shift the wave according to that intervall to zero

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.Spectrogram(WF, kernel, tau, sigma, t0, t1, n)[source]¶

Constructs a spectogram of function WF, i.e. computes the frequencies components for n time bins between t0 and t1. The result is a 2D function along time and frequency axis. ‘kernel’ and ‘sigma’ denote the window function and half-width that is used for computing the Fourier transform for a given time bin of width ‘tau’. ‘tau’ is usually chosen such that the bins overlap.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.StrainToCGS(h, M)[source]¶

Converts time domain strain to CGS units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.StrainToSI(h, M)[source]¶

Converts time domain strain to SI units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.TanhWindow(WF, t0, sigma0, t1, sigma1)[source]¶

Applies a tanh filter to the waveform where t0, t1 denote the blending positions and sigma0 and sigma1 the widths of blending

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.TimesToSI(t, M)[source]¶

Converts a list of time values to SI units

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.UnitStep(x)[source]¶

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DataAnalysis.WienerDiscreteScalarProduct(hSI1, hSI2, d, Sn, fLow, fHi)[source]¶

Given a reconstructed h1 and h2 in SI units in Fourier domain and distance d (in Mpc) this computes the discrete Wiener scalar product for sensitivity curve Sn

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DiscreteFunction module¶

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DiscreteFunction.AlignOverRange(DF1, DF2, x0, x1, start_xoff, delta, dx, accuracy=0.01, monotonic=False)[source]¶

Aligns two functions by minimizing their difference in the L2 norm and returns the x-shift that needs to be applied. [x0,x1]: The minimization interval. start_xoff: An initial guess to speed up computation. delta: the shift will be applied in the range [start_xoff-delta, start_xoff+delta].

The smaller delta, the faster (but keep in mind that you need to be sure that the minimum is located in that range!

dx: The delta spacing of interpolated function values on which the pointwise difference is taken. accuracy: The accuracy in finding the shift that minimizes the L2 norm of the error (‘the delta spacing of the shift’). monotonic: Set to ‘True’ if function is monotonic (this will greatly speed up computation)

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.DiscreteFunction.Blend(DF1, DF2, x0, x1, a=<function <lambda>>)[source]¶

Blend two functions DF1->Df2 over an intervall [x0,x1] using function a: [0,1]->[0,1]. The blending is applied according to the convex combination (1-a)*DF1 + a*DF2 where a takes values in [0,1]. Usually, this is just the identity, i.e. a(x)=x.

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.RadiatedQuantities module¶

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.RadiatedQuantities.RadiatedAngMomFlux(int_rPsi4_ModeArray, int_int_rPsi4_ModeArray, lmax)[source]¶

Given the first and second time integral of rPsi4 (l,m) modes (DiscreteFunction mode arrays), this function computes the radiated angular momentum flux (Lx, Ly, Lz) that is emitted as a function of time in units of [M].

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.RadiatedQuantities.RadiatedEnergyFlux(int_rPsi4_ModeArray, lmax)[source]¶

Given the time integral of rPsi4 (l,m) modes (a DiscreteFunction mode array), this function computes the radiated energy flux that is emitted as a function of time in units of [M].

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.RadiatedQuantities.RadiatedEnergyFluxRWZM(Qeven, Qodd, lmax)[source]¶

Given the time integral of rPsi4 (l,m) modes (a DiscreteFunction mode array), this function computes the radiated energy flux that is emitted as a function of time in units of [M].

CactusTool.Lib.pygwanalysis.RadiatedQuantities.RadiatedLinMomFlux(int_rPsi4_ModeArray, lmax)[source]¶

Given the first time integral of rPsi4 (l,m) modes (DiscreteFunction mode array), this function computes the radiated linear momentum flux (Px, Py, Pz) that is emitted as a function of time in units of [M].
